How would I be able to optimise sales and revenue if I were able to have 100% knowledge of my entire inventory at all times, and live sales data.

Having complete knowledge of your inventory and real-time sales data can certainly help you optimize sales and revenue in a number of ways. Here are a few ideas:

1. You can use the inventory data to ensure that you have the right products in stock at the right time. If you know what items are selling quickly, you can make sure to restock those items so that you don't run out.
2. You can use the sales data to identify trends and make informed decisions about what products to order more of, and which ones to de-emphasize.
3. You can use the data to identify slow-selling items and consider running promotions or sales to try to move those products.
4. You can use the data to identify your best-selling products and try to cross-sell or upsell related items to customers.
5. You can use the data to optimize your pricing strategy. For example, if you see that certain items are selling well at a higher price point, you might consider raising the price of those items.
6. You can use the data to optimize your inventory levels. If you have real-time data on what is selling and at what rate, you can adjust your inventory levels accordingly to minimize excess inventory and reduce waste.

These are just a few ideas, and there are many other ways that having real-time data on your inventory and sales could help you optimize your business.
Would you say most high street stores have complete knowledge of their inventory? Do they have software in place to achieve this?

It depends on the store and the size of their inventory. Some stores, especially larger ones, may have more sophisticated inventory management systems in place that allow them to have a high level of visibility into their inventory. These systems may include software that tracks inventory levels in real-time and alerts store personnel when it is time to reorder. However, smaller stores or stores with less complex inventory systems may not have the same level of visibility into their inventory. In general, though, most retailers try to maintain as much control over their inventory as possible in order to optimize sales and minimize waste.
So is there a gap in the market to develop a system which provides complete visibility of inventory and collects real-time sales data, and then provides recommendations based on analytics.

It is certainly possible that there is a gap in the market for a system that provides complete visibility into inventory and real-time sales data and offers recommendations based on analytics. Retail is a competitive industry, and retailers are always looking for ways to gain an advantage over their competitors. If you were able to develop such a system and effectively market it to retailers, it could potentially be a successful business venture. However, it is also worth noting that there are already many existing inventory management and point-of-sale (POS) systems on the market that offer various levels of functionality and analytics, so you would need to carefully evaluate the market and consider how your system would be differentiated from the competition.
